displayed_text: Patient: Yes. Um hum. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Patient: Well, so. Doctor: Alright. You know, we can, there are other options there for you. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Are you able to have an erection at all with the pills? Patient: Uh, you know, I’ve been having, you know, just like something happening, and- Doctor: But it’s not effective enough that you can have sex with it? Is that what you’re saying? Patient: Uh, well, I have, but, you know, it’s like I wanted to get better, you know, so. Doctor: Okay. So you’re able to have an erection enough that you can penetrate the vagina? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So you want to get better?

Patient: I see. Doctor: That’s the criteria. Patient: I see. Doctor: So this PSMA scan picks up those normal things that are too small. So often patients will get upstaged in a way where you thought you had five things and told that you have ten. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you’ve got to be prepared for that kind of news that there’s more there. Patient: Well I mean it’s- Doctor: It’s not always like that but it’s possible. Patient: No. No. No. It’s better to know what you’re dealing with than not. What about the treatment side of it in Europe? I mean what do they do once, let’s say you’re a candidate. Then they, do they attach to the uh to the antibody? Doctor: Well, so it’s not an antibody. Patient: Oh. Its an enzyme, enzyme.. Doctor: It’s a, uh, it’s a little very tiny little piece of just a little chemical.

Family Member: You do?! Doctor: Yeah, yeah, we do zap. Yeah. Family Member: My creativity works dear. Doctor: There are several things going on at once, zapping one or two won't slow down anything. We only zap-. So here's the scenario when we would do that, okay. Okay. We give you the stuff and you're, you're on cruise control with Xtandi and your PSA is zero and looking great. And every time we scan you only have two of these spots in your ribs that just won't go away. Family Member: Light up. Doctor: So then we radiate those two and then see if we can just keep them longer. Family Member: So you can radiate? Doctor: We can radiate anywhere. Family Member: So in C___ Dr. F____ can radiate. Doctor: Dr. F____ can radiate it. If it’s needed. Now, he won't just willy nilly do it unless you have pain, or we've shown that everything about you is stable and those are the only two areas that’s acting up. Family Member: Well, that’s good to know that. I didn’t know that. Doctor: Yeah see you’re not just out there.

Patient: So it’s going to be? Doctor: But up until now, it’s been this kind of almost called hit or miss, and just because of the way we did things in the U.S., it hasn’t. It’s been very frustrating. And I told you I went to Turkey to some little hospital taking care of this guy. We can give him We invented it. I can’t give it at my hospital. Patient: Oh. Oh. Doctor: So it’s been used in that way around the world but not, I’m not allowed to. Patient: That’s so tough. I see. Family Member: So it has pretty good results in Germany? Doctor: And so what they’ve done different than we do here is they report it on their experience. So they’re like we treated these six-hundred people, people with different stage, and different things, and they try to give some data about how the people live, what was their survival, and they showed you know tumor shrinking, and their response rate. And so overall that Gestalt, that’s a German word. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That looks, looks really good, I think. And then they collaborate with this gentleman that I have experience with in Turkey, seeing the data presented. I mean you share but you know some of the data that shows incredible responses to these. So I think part of it depends on how active your cancer is for this study, for this, this for the PSMA. Patient: Okay. Okay. Family Member: And then if you see the result, you would know probably in two months if you saw the results? Doctor: Yes.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: It was a man that invented that transfusion and some other stuff they invented. What ever happened to him? Doctor: You know it’s not a transfusion, right? Patient: Right. Doctor: Yeah. So a transfusion means- Patient: I mean, you know, he, you know- Doctor: Infusion. Patient: Infusion. Yes. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: He invented that infusion. Doctor: Yes. Patient: So whatever happened to him? Doctor: I’m not sure if any one man invented it. So it’s a company called, D___, so it’s several scientists that have figured that out. I have no idea what’s happened to them but the company, you know, is still alive and well, and, they, we give the stuff all the time to people. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, you know, then based on sort of what we do see, we’re gonna sort of pinpoint that. Patient: Okay. Tallyho. Doctor: And, so, other thoughts or questions? So, typically, what we would do is I’m gonna give you a prescription for a pill drug today. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, you take it, you take it for thirty days and then you stop. Uh, in two weeks you come in and you get your first hormone shot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Then you and I just have to pick a day when you wanna start chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, some of it is, you can look at a calendar. The end of the year is coming. You know, Christmas, New Year’s, Thanksgiving. You know, what day, eh, do you wanna plan it out. ‘Cuz once we get started, it’s gonna be every three weeks. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? You’re gonna come in two weeks which would be the twenty-first. You could theoretically get your first chemo then. You may also say, “Uh, no, let’s wait two more weeks.” Patient: Until the third of January or something.

Patient: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Doctor: That’s one perspective, okay? Patient: Sure. Doctor: So the other thing, so we’ve got this fifty/fifty with the hormones and radiation. The question is what else can we do. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So what else we can do is we can hit what’s remaining as far as the cancer really hard right now and when I say really hard what we’re talking about is some chemotherapy, um which we give you through the vein every three weeks and we give you four doses of it. It’s a medicine called Taxotere. And we add in um uh, if we can get insurance to pay for it, but generally we can; we add in a super-hormone medicine called ah Zytiga or Addaram. It’s a pill you take ah every day. It’s four pills every day. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So that’s quite frankly that’s a, it’s a clinical trial we offer, but because of a stupid loophole which I didn’t realize I can’t put you on the clinical trial because you were on the other one. (Laughs) Patient: Right. Doctor: And uhm it’s a loophole I’m going to fix. Patient: Uh hum. Patient: Right.

Family Member: It didn’t tell you --- Doctor: No, I wanted to know how much Neanderthal was in me. (Laughs) Doctor: Right, right. Patient: But that’s, uh, not so much the case anymore. That --- Doctor: Or how much – I’ve been watching these alien shows. I wanna learn how much alien Patient: Oh good, good. Doctor: Alien DNA. Patient: My doctor watches the alien shows (laughs) Family Member: That’s everyone. Does that make you feel better. Patient: Okay great, man. I feel great now. I just, I just took the survey “Do I trust my doctor?” I gotta go back and change it. Doctor: Oh, my lord. Doctor: I find it interesting because they, not about the alien part, but they tell you a lot of cool stuff about weird places on earth that you didn’t know about. You’re like, oh, that’s kind of a cool place over there in, you know, Bulgaria or something.

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …we tend to treat it systemically. Patient: Okay. Doctor: …with pills or IV or whatnot which we’ll talk about. So I don’t want to cut you open, but I do want to re-biopsy you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and I talked to our radiologist. He’s gonna see at the time that you’re on the table of the CAT scan what is the best area to target because these things all move as well. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Preferably the largest one because it’s an easier target, but we want to make sure that one, it’s safe for you. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Number two, that we can get enough samples. So here the ‘enough’ means that we’d like to get some stuff for testing? Patient: Right. Doctor: Just regular hey what’s on the pathology? Patient: Mhmm.

Family Member: Three months. So at what point does the prostate shrink? Doctor: That’s our hope. Family Member: OHH! Patient: So should I be wearing this catheter for a while then? Doctor: Well because again it could be as early as this week that they feel like you can pee on your own. But if that’s what they’re going to be testing - Patient: And they cannot test it any other way except by pulling it out. Doctor: Right. Patient: Putting it in. Two times they put it in. And both times I was in E.R., and there were some nurses that were putting it in, they said they were experienced by they were not. They couldn’t do it properly. It was going the wrong way. And then uh the first time over the overnight, and the next day another nurse came from urology department. And she was able to do it. The second time when I went for only one night, again two local nurses you know tried to put it in, they couldn’t do it. They did it wrong. And then they called the urologist that was on duty and she came. She was a Doctor: I’m with ya. Okay, so how’s your appetite? Patient: It’s fine . My wife changed the diet completely; now I’ve been Family Member: And I was bringing him food but didn’t eat that food, it was horrible. And now his appetite is really good. Doctor: And your bowels are moving daily?

Patient: I’ll go with that line of action first. Doctor: And then you’re going to say, boy, that doctor, she’s really smart. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Be sure you don’t like, you know, sleep so hard that you forget to pee if you actually have to pee. Doctor: I’m just saying seven p.m. Okay. Bye. Patient: Okay. So I got – she took – oh, I do, right here. Doctor: You do have sheet to go. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Alright. See you guys soon.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: They, they uh, I don’t think they’ve worked out totally the scheme of what’s the best way to do it, every two months at most it’s been. Each center does it slightly different. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh but that’s, that’s about what they do. Uh I’m not really sure because they haven’t seen profound bone marrow effects. One of the problems with radioactive things is you can get- Patient: Sure. Um hum. Doctor: Injury to the bone marrow. My experience with them is that particularly with patients who’ve had, not had a lot of chemotherapy, so not a lot of things to injure the bone marrow, they don’t seem to really have a problem with bone marrow toxicity from this study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The only place they run into problems is if somebody comes with you know five-hundred things in the bowel, and we’re putting this radiation in cancer, in terms of next to the bone cells, those people mostly get bone marrow problems. But in regard to you, I would expect probably not from the bone marrow. Family Member: Can you get him in this? Doctor: Well the German thing is you know unfortunately you’d have to pay for it. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So it’s not a study.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Or we could not and just go straight to surgery, do the re-routing that we talked about last time – Patient: Right. Doctor: And do the study after. Either way, the comforting part is there is a potential next treatment that is – Patient: Okay. So, so how come I can’t do, do the pills and do the treatment, too? Can I do both? Doctor: No, no, no. You could the, you could do the pills. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But when you’re on pills like that, experimental ones – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You don’t want to have some big surgery, be scheduled in the middle of it. Doesn’t make sense. Because you have to do one at a time. Patient: I got you. Doctor: Because it’s a big sur – I mean it’s a big one. (Cell phone rings)

Patient: I am, totally. Doctor: I mean, that, you know? Patient: I’m having fun. Doctor: That’s a scale. I mean that’s amazing. Wow. When you’re talented, you’re talented. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And there’s nothing like cancer that’s going to stop you. Family Member: No. Patient: No. It ain’t going to stop me. I’ve got to do what I’ve got to do. It ain’t going to stop me. I’ve got to be a superstar. It’s not going to stop me. Patient: Now that I’ll get you and we’ll shoot a video. Doctor: Oh. Patient: Video. Doctor: Oh, man. Yes! Let’s do it! You got to give me a heads up.

Family Member: For two years. Doctor: Yeah. Different people. I’m overstating it a little bit, but people are more tired. And uh, but people are more tired. And, and but if you exercise, it’s not as bad. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you don’t have the side effects of an increased heart attack risk. You don’t have, your bones don’t get soft, your muscles don’t go weak; you know exercise is the key here. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Um, but um some guys have bad hot flashes. And some guys get depressed because their metabolism down. Um, but make no mistake, people keep working; they keep enjoying life; they’re just more tired. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: The super hormones for the three months also make you more tired, but not really that much more because once we lower your testosterone down to what we call castrate levels, to go from castrate to super castrate, people don’t complain about more tiredness. Patient: Right. Doctor: So um there are some things we watch and your blood tests to make sure you’re tolerating the drugs all right, but that’s not the big issue. Tiredness is the issue. So then we add chemo in and really we give the chemo to you four times on a Monday – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - three weeks apart. Um, the the actual um chemo itself, you don’t get sick, you don’t throw up. We have all the medicines that stop that from happening. Anything that throw up We’re just really good at it. Uhm, Patient: Sure.
